title: College And Critical Thinking
summary:
Key ideas
- Critical thinking is the ability to score highly on the Watson-Glaser Critical Thinking Appraisal.
- Many studies that attempt to measure the effects of college on critical thinking skills lack control groups.
- There are two studies with moderately good designs:  one study follows 30 college students and 17 non-college students, and the second study compares full-time and part-time college students.
- Some studies suggest that most of the gains in critical thinking skills in college happen in the first year.
- Studying a lot and reading unassigned books seems to help develop critical thinking.
- Relationships with competitive and uninvolved peer groups are more likely to show gains in critical thinking than supportive and belonging ones.

Key learnings
- People will gain critical thinking skills during the four years from age 18 to age 22.
- College helps a little with critical thinking skills, and there are dose-dependent effects of college.
- The effect sizes range from modest to appreciable.
- It is difficult to interpret whether the effect of college on critical thinking is real, as confounding variables persist.

Key questions
- What is critical thinking?
- What study designs exist to measure the effect of college on critical thinking?
- Do the effects of college on critical thinking last, or do they diminish over time?
- What are the specific aspects of the college experience that enhance critical thinking development?
